posts.post_content: The new art is stunning and this card is still as dominant as it ever was, even in lieu of its recent Angelic competition in the form of [Baneslayer Angel](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Baneslayer Angel). The one thing that remains a mystery is, what was Wizards thinking when they released Divine vs Demonic? [Akroma, Angel of Wrath](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Akroma, Angel of Wrath) is perhaps the greatest testament to how utterly imbalanced this Duel Decks series was - the {B} deck simply cannot contain the domination of Akroma, especially considering she has protection against anything the Demonic crew can throw at her...
posts.html:
The new art is stunning and this card is still as dominant as it ever was, even in lieu of its recent Angelic competition in the form of Baneslayer Angel. The one thing that remains a mystery is, what was Wizards thinking when they released Divine vs Demonic? Akroma, Angel of Wrath is perhaps the greatest testament to how utterly imbalanced this Duel Decks series was - the {B} deck simply cannot contain the domination of Akroma, especially considering she has protection against anything the Demonic crew can throw at her...

posts.post_content: @raverboy1123 - Jedijoe is right, Akroma dies to [Reiver Demon](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Reiver Demon) due to its ability not being a targeting or damage effect (which pro black would otherwise prevent), but one that simply says to destroy ***all*** nonblack, nonartifact creatures on the battlefield. No targeting and no damage is mentioned because there is none involved. Nice try raverboy and look more closely when comparing the rules and text next time.
posts.html:

Posted By: SolidSoldier (6/9/2010 11:59:15 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: @raverboy1123 - Look again, the [Reiver Demon](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Reiver Demon) doesn't deal damage to anyone or anything when it comes into play, rather it destroys, and since it doesn't specifically target, creatures like [Akroma, Angel of Wrath](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Akroma, Angel of Wrath) WOULD perish to it. If it didn't as you have stated, then other creatures like [Progenitus](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Progenitus) wouldn't die from a [Wrath of God](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wrath of God), even though Wizards has clearly stated that it can due to the effect that [Wrath of God](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wrath of God) gives to the entire battlefield. Much like the [Reiver Demon](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Reiver Demon)'s ability.
posts.html:
@raverboy1123 - Look again, the Reiver Demon doesn't deal damage to anyone or anything when it comes into play, rather it destroys, and since it doesn't specifically target, creatures like Akroma, Angel of Wrath WOULD perish to it. If it didn't as you have stated, then other creatures like Progenitus wouldn't die from a Wrath of God, even though Wizards has clearly stated that it can due to the effect that Wrath of God gives to the entire battlefield. Much like the Reiver Demon's ability.

posts.post_content: ok *geniouses* as to the debate as to whether or not reiver demon destroys akroma, the answer is no akroma survives sorry **eved, sarroth** you really should actually look at the rules before posting wishfull bs. according to article 702.14e of the shadow proclamation aka MTg comprehensive rulebook: Any damage that would be dealt by sources that have the stated quality to a permanent or player with protection is prevented.
